isis.stitle: Recall 96508 - Eaton Rear Axle with Axilok Wheel Adjusting Nuts

recall.subject: Eaton Rear Axle with Axilok Wheel Adjusting Nuts

defect.para:
This Recall applies to 2554, 2574, 2654, 2674, 4700, 4800, 4900, 5000, 8100, 8200, 9200, 9300, 9400, and 9800 models built 04/16/1996 through 10/16/1996 with Eaton rear axle housings with a date code prior to HU 0605XXX or P 0605XXX. NOTE: The first 4 digits represent the Julian date code of March 1, 1995 which is to be considered the good in effect date; any axle with a Julian date prior to this number must be repaired.
(The first three digits of the Julian date code identifies the day of the year, 1-366, and the fourth digit identifies the year; 5 represents 1995.) The digits following the first four digits denote a sequential serial number built that day. Reference Figure 1 for location of tag with date code. Reference Figure 2 for sample tags.

Navistar first started using the Axilok wheel nut on 04/16/1996. This new style nut required a longer draw key slot in the axle housing end to accommodate the Axilok wheel nut lock tab. The supplier inadvertently shipped some older housings built with the shorter draw key slot to Navistar assembly plants. The shorter slot could possibly cause the Axilok wheel nut lock tab to fail from cracking caused by overloads during assembly followed by fatigue during service.

para.emph: Should a wheel nut lock tab fail, the rear wheel assembly could separate from the axle housing. Should this happen, the disengaged wheel assembly could pose a hazard to other users of the roadway and adjacent property. This condition would also affect vehicle stability and control and could cause a vehicle crash without prior warning, possibly resulting in property damage or personal injury.

defect.para: Owners will be notified of this campaign on their vehicles by Navistar. A listing of owner names and addresses has been furnished to the involved dealers to enable dealers to follow up with owners to have the vehicles corrected. You must limit the use of this listing to this campaign since the list may contain information obtained from state motor vehicle registration records and the use of such motor vehicle registration data for purposes other than this campaign is a violation of law in several states.

svcproc.stitle: Recall 96508 - Eaton Rear Axle with Axilok Wheel Adjusting Nuts
svcproc.title: SERVICE PROCEDURE

step1.para: Inspect forward rear and rear rear axle housing date code referencing Figure 1 and Figure 2.
If date code is HU or P 0605 or newer (March 1, 1995 Julian date), do nothing. Vehicle is deemed to have correct housing.

If date code is HU or P 0605 or older (March 1, 1995 Julian date), the Axilok wheel nuts must be removed and standard wheel nuts and lock rings installed ON ALL REAR AXLES so there is no mix of wheel nuts on a vehicle.
Wheel end play should be set per CTS-5137T.
Install new axle shaft gaskets and torque axle shaft mounting nuts to 275-300 ft-lbs.

note.para: If a bad housing is found on a tandem axle, the wheel nuts must be changed on BOTH axles so there is no mix of wheel nuts on the vehicle.

entry.para: Inspect housings for date code only
Inspect for date code; remove Axilok Wheel Nuts; install standard wheel nuts, single axle
Inspect for date code; remove Axilok Wheel Nuts; install standard wheel nuts, tandem axle

responuscan.para:
Proceed immediately to make necessary correction to units in inventory. All inventory vehicles subject to this recall campaign must be corrected prior to sale, transfer or delivery.
If vehicles have been sold or transferred and you are in receipt of Customer Notification Letters and Authorization for Recall Service cards for those vehicles, transfer location or customer must be notified from your dealer location.

Dealers must correct all vehicles subject to this campaign at no charge to the owner, regardless of mileage, age of vehicle, or ownership, from this time forward. The National Traffic and Motor Vehicle Safety Act, as amended, provides that each vehicle that is subject to a vehicle recall campaign must be adequately repaired within a reasonable time after the owner has tendered it for repair. A failure to adequately repair within 60 days after a tender of a vehicle is prima facie evidence of failure to repair within a reasonable time. If the condition is not adequately repaired within 60 days, the owner may be entitled to replacement with an identical or reasonable equivalent vehicle at no charge, or to a refund of the purchase price less a reasonable allowance for depreciation.

In order to avoid having to replace an owner vehicle or refund the purchase price, every effort must be made to promptly schedule an appointment with each owner to repair the vehicle as soon as possible.

claims.para: Refer to Dealer Warranty Manual for procedures to conduct Recall Campaigns.

It is important that the Recall Coding be completed properly to assist in processing the warranty claim. Complete instructions will be found in the Warranty Manual, Section 7-1. Special attention should be given to Items 39 through 44:
